channel.title: Assembly for Human Rights: Montreal
channel.description:
This special series offers highlights of a 1968 international gathering held in Montreal, Quebec, bringing together some 80 unofficial delegates and observers from all parts of the world. The assembly was presented in connection with the current International Year of Human Rights declared by UNESCO (United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization).

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: Meet the delegate, part 1
item.description: This program features informal interviews with three prominent assembly participants, two of them from Nigeria and one from the only communist nation represented, Yugoslavia: Chief S.O. Adebo, Nigeria, Undersecretary-General, U.N.; A.A. Mohammed, Nigeria, U.S. Commission on Human Rights; Anton Vratusa, Yugoslavia, Ambassador to the U.N.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: Yugoslavia

item.title: Summing up, part 2
item.description: As the assembly nears its conclusion, the time has come for a summing up of the outstanding ideas and proposals for action to come out of this important meeting. This final program includes remarks by Dr. William Korey, director, B'nai Brith U.N. Office; Rev. Herschel Halbert; Manouchehr Ganji, Iran; Clark Eichelberger, U.N. Association of the U.S.; and Leslie Paffrath, moderator.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World politics--20th century

item.title: Science and technology as threats, part 1
item.description: This program features an address by Lord Ritchie-Calder, a Scottish science writer, on science and technology and their implications as possible threats to individual freedom.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World politics--20th century

item.title: Recent progress and challenges ahead, part 2
item.description: An introduction to the conference, which brought together 80 distinguished delegates and observers from many parts of the world to discuss the vital work remaining to be done on the issues envisioned by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights adopted by the General Assembly of the UN in December, 1948. It features remarks by Louis B. Sohn, Harvard University; Georges Aronstein, Belgian League for the Rights of Man; Sir Senerat Gunewardene, UN Commission on Human Rights; and Leslie Paffrath, assembly co-chair and president of The Johnson Foundation.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World politics--20th century

item.title: Recent progress and challenges ahead, part 1
item.description: An introduction to the conference, which brought together 80 distinguished delegates and observers from many parts of the world to discuss the vital work remaining to be done on the issues envisioned by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights adopted by the General Assembly of the UN in December, 1948. It features remarks by Louis B. Sohn, Harvard University; Georges Aronstein, Belgian League for the Rights of Man; Sir Senerat Gunewardene, UN Commission on Human Rights; and Leslie Paffrath, assembly co-chair and president of The Johnson Foundation.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World politics--20th century

item.title: Outlook in three typical democracies, part 2
item.description: This program pinpoints contrasting human rights challenges in three widely separated democracies, each with their own unique outlook on the subject: Maxwell Cohen, McGill University, Montreal; Judge Gustav Petren, Sweden; and E.R. Richardson, ambassador to the U.S. from Jamaica.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World politics--20th century

item.title: Outlook in three typical democracies, part 1
item.description: This program pinpoints contrasting human rights challenges in three widely separated democracies, each with their own unique outlook on the subject: Maxwell Cohen, McGill University, Montreal; Judge Gustav Petren, Sweden; and E.R. Richardson, ambassador to the U.S. from Jamaica.

item.title: Women's rights, part 2
item.description: This prog.: Women's Rights. Mrs. helvi Sipila, delegate of the UN Commission on the Status of Women; Sir H.O.B. Wooding, Court of Appeals, Trinidad and Tobago; Justice Haim H. Cohn, Israel Supreme Court; Manouchehr Ganji
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World politics--20th century

item.title: Women's rights, part 1
item.description: This program focuses on women's rights, including such specific issues as voting privileges, employment and working conditions, education, and maternity and childcare rights. Speakers: Helvi Sipila, delegate of the UN Commission on the Status of Women; Sir H.O.B. Wooding, Court of Appeals, Trinidad and Tobago; Justice Haim H. Cohn, Israel Supreme Court; and Manouchehr Ganji, human rights activist and former minister of education of Iran.
item.dc:creator: University of Wisconsin
item.dc:subject: World politics--20th century
